title: The exec who swims with real sharks
text:
AFR Oct 7, 2019 — 10.07am Share

R

oz Gregory is head of Customer Success & Digital Transformation, Asia-Pacific, at Pivotal Software.

Why swimming and how did you get into it?

I’ve always loved the water – happier in it than out – and there was a great group of mums from school that carpooled every morning to Manly [in Sydney]. I was so envious, I think they read my mind because I scored an invite and that sealed the deal. I was hooked from day one and now I love to bore people to death about the benefits of ocean swimming.

Pool or ocean?

The ocean. It’s like that moment in Pretty Woman where Edward takes Vivian to the opera and explains, “People’s reactions to opera the first time they see it is very dramatic. They either love it or they hate it.” That’s ocean swimming. Once I tried it, I couldn’t go back. It continually pushes you out of your comfort zone – do you like huge surf? Will you be comfortable swimming with sharks? Can you handle the stingers? Pool swimming is useful when I’m travelling for work across Asia, but the ocean has my soul.

How often do you train?

I try to get to Manly three or four times a week. A lot depends on my kids’ schedule, but every night, the group checks in on the app and a carload commits. There’s always hilarious commentary, and empathy, with the usual theme being that we’re all pretty grateful to have a holiday each morning before we start our real day.

Usual distance?

On a normal weekday, we swim 1.5 kilometres across Cabbage Tree Bay in Manly. In summer, we do 2.5km and 6km swims. We also participate in the Cole Classic at Manly and the Byron Bay and Whitehaven Beach (Hamilton Island) ocean swims. Next spring, we’re off to Greece to swim some longer distances, which will be fun. I’m not sure I’m the channel-swimming type, but I do admire their gumption.

Gregory is not in it for the competition but enjoys a swim in the Cole Classic event with friends. James Alcock

Do you swim year round or just in summer?

No fair-weather swimming here. We go 365 days a year, rain or shine. I don’t wear a wetsuit because they make me uncomfortable, and they’re bloody hard work to get on. In winter, the temperature can drop down to about 15 degrees and your face feels like it’s freezing off. But mostly it stays around 16-17 degrees, which is fresh.

What do you enjoy most about ocean swimming?

The clarity and abundant sea life are extraordinary, and that’s the crux of it. Ocean swimming is not just about the exercise. For me, it’s not competitive, which is a relief because most of my life I’ve been super results oriented. Ocean swimming gives me a break from all that. It’s an ongoing exercise in presence and acceptance.

What do you think about when swimming?

A huge benefit for me is the mental health factor – my stress seems to dissipate. I dissect work, kids, relationships, global warming, even The Handmaid’s Tale, but the idea is just to lose yourself in the motion.

Tell us the swimmer you most admire

We swam with Susie O’Neill at a Whitehaven Beach Ocean Swim event. She’s there most years and I was quite giddy when we met her. She was such a champion and still looks and swims like a star.

Ever been in trouble swimming?

Not long ago, we swam in huge surf and a lot of swimmers were getting out. As I swam back with a pal, the waves were growing and an old Manly Surf Life Saving Club pro who was with us shouted over the booming surf, “They’re coming in big sets of four with a smaller two, and this is number three, so go now!” We swam for our lives. My heart hasn’t raced like that since I jumped out of a plane. I was pretty relieved to exit safely that day and even more grateful for the caring community of Manly ocean swimmers. The beach closed shortly after.

Any bugbears?

We all agree the Manly Surf Life Saving Club change rooms could do with some love.

description: Ocean swimming has so many things going for it, says Pivotal Software’s head of customer success and digital transformation. She answers our Time Out Q&A.
